resources.string: Transform your nights with DreamGuard. Join us to improve your sleep quality and take control of your well-being

To understand your sleep, please answer a few questions from us. Your honest answers will make the results more accurate. The information you provide will be used for our sleep analysis models, and your privacy will be strictly protected
Enter your email address to reset password
Stay connected to your sleep health journey
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your gender
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your age
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know how many hours you sleep a day
Your journey to better sleep continues here
Just follow the link we sent to:
If you doesn’t receive an email you can resend the verification email in 0:59
How many hours do you \nsleep a day?
On a scale of 1 to 10, what is your sleep quality?
On a scale of 1 to 10, what is \nyour activity and stress level?
How many daily steps do you take in a day?
What is your current heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure?
My daily steps a day is:
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your sleep quality on a scale of 1 to 10 (1 is poor, 10 is good)
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your activity level (1 very low, 10 is very high) and stress level (1 is very low, 10 is very high)
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know weight and height for calculating your BMI. For better accuracy, you can use a suitable tool for measuring
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your current occupation
In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know your daily steps in a day. If you not keeping track, you can spend a day and use a pedometer or step counter app to count your step

In order to provide a suitable result for you, we need to know this information. You can use a tensimeter to find out all three. If you are confused about which one is which, you can see the instructions in this article
Analyzing your data to provide \npersonalized insights and \nrecommendations. . . . .
We've Identified No Sleep Disorder In Your Results

Great news! Our prediction shows that you don\'t have any sleep disorders. This means you\'re doing an awesome job taking care of your health and sleep! Keep it up and even aim to elevate your health and sleep to the next level to keep enjoying all the benefits for your body! Don\'t forget to maintain your sleep schedule of at least 8 hours and manage your stress levels.
You\'re getting less than 8 hours of sleep, but don\'t worry! We've got some fun tips for you!
Your stress level is hitting 8–10, it\'s time to take some fun steps to boost your mood!
Create a cozy sleep space by keeping your room dark and cool—maybe add some soft warm lights for a nice touch!
Remember to unplug those gadgets at least 30 minutes before bed, as the blue light can mess with your sleep.
Wind down with a good book or some relaxing meditation to ease your mind! Be mindful of caffeine and heavy meals close to bedtime, and regular exercise can really help!
Try deep breathing techniques, like the 4–7–8 method—inhale for 4 seconds, hold for 7, and exhale for 8!
Schedule some "me time", whether it’s hanging out with friends or diving into a beloved hobby.
Eating healthy foods can boost both your body and mind.
Lastly, don’t hesitate to chat with someone about how you feel, whether it\'s a friend or a professional.

Our prediction indicates you may have sleep apnea. This condition can affect your overall well-being and energy levels. Don\'t worry—we're here to help you take positive steps towards better sleep health!
Taking these steps, along with professional guidance, can enhance your sleep quality and overall health. Let’s embark on this journey to better sleep together—your best rest awaits!
Create a Relaxing Atmosphere: Transform your room into a cozy haven—dark, quiet, and cool—for the ultimate relaxation.
Regular Sleep Schedule: Stick to a regular sleep schedule to keep your body in sync and energized.
CPAP Therapy: Discuss using a CPAP machine for open-airway bliss with your doctor.
Oral Appliances: Consider handy oral devices to keep your airway open.
Weight Management: Embrace a healthy diet and fun exercises.
Sleep Position: Sleep on your side to reduce airway obstruction.
Avoid Alcohol and Sedatives: Skip alcohol and sedatives before bed for a refreshing sleep journey.
Make your bedroom your sleep sanctuary: it cool, quiet, and dark. And ditch the TV or screen time before bed—those blue lights mess with your sleep-wake cycle, making it harder to fall asleep.
Get moving, but not too late: Aim for regular physical activity during the day—just make sure to wrap it up at least 5–6 hours before bed, so you don’t end up too wired to sleep.
Watch what you consume: Avoid caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol close to bedtime. While alcohol might help you drift off initially, it can disrupt your sleep later in the night, leaving you wide awake.
No afternoon naps: As tempting as they are, naps can mess with your ability to sleep well at night. Keep your nap short or skip it altogether.
Eat at regular times: Avoid heavy meals right before bed. Your body will thank you for keeping your digestive system on a regular schedule.

Manage your stress: Try winding down with a calming routine—read a book, listen to soothing music, or take a relaxing bath. If stress is still hanging around, yoga, meditation, or even acupuncture could do wonders.
Be mindful of meds: Certain over-the-counter or prescription drugs can mess with your sleep. Talk to your doctor about alternatives if needed.
Stick to a sleep schedule: Try to go to bed and wake up around the same time each day, even on weekends. Consistency is key to training your body’s internal clock.

We\'ve noticed signs that you might be experiencing insomnia, which could be affecting your sleep quality. It\'s important to address this early to prevent it from impacting your overall health. Focus on establishing a consistent sleep routine, managing stress, and creating a relaxing bedtime environment. Taking steps now can help improve your sleep and well-being. Remember, you're not alone in this, and with the right strategies, you can get your sleep back on track!
We've Identified Sleep Insomnia In Your Results
Here are some practical and easy-to-follow tips to help you reclaim your restful nights:

But if these tips don\'t do the trick, don’t worry—Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT–I) might be your next step! This 6–8 week program is designed to help you fall asleep faster and stay asleep longer, by teaching you practical sleep skills and helping you break the cycle of sleepless nights. Plus, it’s effective for long-term insomnia. CBT-I can be done by a doctor, nurse, or therapist; you can do it in person, by telephone, or online.
Cognitive therapy: Helps you stop stressing about not sleeping, which ironically makes it easier to sleep.
Relaxation/meditation therapy: you how to calm your mind and fall asleep faster.
Sleep education: you build good sleep habits that last.
Sleep restriction therapy: counterintuitive, but by limiting the time you spend in bed, you’ll gradually start to sleep better and longer.

Stimulus control therapy: you associate your bed with sleep, not tossing and turning. You’ll learn to only go to bed when sleepy, get up if you can’t sleep, and reserve your bed for sleeping (and, you know, other activities).
Ready to sleep like a champ? Start with these tips, and if needed, give CBT-I a go! Your best sleep is just around the corner.
